This frail structure of piled - up hypotheses must be approached with due caution,  as must the ifurther suggestion that there may be a ritual connection between the scourging of the Spartan boys and that ( or the expulsion ) of the Pharmakoi at the Thargelia at Athens and in other Ionian states.  The view that would see in the scourging a pre - nuptial fertility - rite is wisely rejected,  and the less unlikely connection with the cheese - stealing ordeal,  mentioned above,  is emphasised,  and embellished with the suggestion that the cheeses were substituted for clay phialai,  like those of Apollo stolen by the original Pharmakos ( p.  264f.  ).  After these exciting speculations we are given a picturesque and indeed attractive conception of the setting of the Parthe - neion^ namely that the troop of maidens had just returned by night ( across TaygetusI ) from a ritual visit to the shrine of Artemis Limnatis,  which would effectively explain their fatigue. 
In chapter VIII »The Subject Population« we may briefly notice the author's interpretation of the conquest of Laconia and Messenia.  For the former she assumes a slow progress as the Dorian invaders came in,  in gradually increasing strength ; and believes that considerable areas had been subdued before the traditional date ( e.  g.  that implied by Strabo ) for its commencement,  c.  800 B.  C. ,  thus rejecting Busolt's theory of an original »Standlager« at Sparta,  in favour of the view of E.  Meyer that the Perioeci were themselves Dorians,  or preferably that a mixed Dorian and pre - Dorian culture extended over the whole of the Eurotas valley and the region east of it®. 
For Messenia,  her view is ( i ) that a predominantly Dorian civilisation,  of an early feudal type,  but centring round independent nohiÇy was already in existence when the Spartans first invaded the country ; ( 2 ) that the first Messenian war,  which resulted in the annexation of the fertile plain of Macaria,  with its serfs »who formed the majority of the later Spartan Helots« was the sequel to a gradual conquest of the coastal region east of the Messenian Gulf,  for which she finds evidence in Homer ; and ( 5 ) that the second war meant the destruction of Andania and the occupation of the plain of Stenyclaros,  and the deliberate de - population of most of the rest of the country ( except Methone and Asine ).
